header.title: THE ZOHAR: Annotations to the Ashlag Commentary

central_thesis: The Zohar, as interpreted by Rav Michael Laitman based on the Ashlag commentary, presents Kabbalah as a practical system for humanity to achieve spiritual perfection and complete unity with the Creator. This is accomplished through a gradual process of internal self-correction, transforming egoistic desires into altruistic ones via intentional spiritual work (MAN, or prayer/request) and the study of authentic Kabbalistic texts, thereby ascending through spiritual degrees (Sefirot and Partzufim) until the 'End of Correction' (Gmar Tikkun). The entire Torah and Zohar speak allegorically of man's inner properties and his relationship with the Creator, providing a precise roadmap for this ascent.

structure_content.summary: Introduces Rabbi Shimon Bar-Yochai (Rashbi) as the author of The Book of Zohar, emphasizing its historical concealment and contemporary revelation. The Zohar is presented not as a historical text, but as an allegorical guide to spiritual reality and man's inner self-correction, crucial for attaining the Creator. It highlights the importance of Baal HaSulam's commentary ('The Ladder') for making this wisdom accessible.

Provides a comprehensive glossary of key Kabbalistic terms including AA, AHP, AVI, Bina, Daat, Elokim, GE, Gematria, Hassadim, Hochma, Ima, Israel, Kabbalist, Kli, Klipot, Lishma, Lo Lishma, MAD, Malchut, MAN, Mashiach, MI, Mitzva, NRNHY, Nukva, Olam, Ohr, Orla, Parsa, Partzuf, Rosh, Sefira/Sefirot, Shechina, Sigim, Sof, Tabur, Taamim, Tzimtzum, VAK, Yesod, YESHSUT, ZA, Zivug, and ZON. This section details the fundamental structure of the spiritual worlds, the ten Sefirot as degrees of remoteness from the Creator, and the Partzuf as a spiritual body with Rosh (head), Toch (interior), and Sof (end).

Explains the two primary spiritual states: Katnut (smallness), characterized by the reception of only Ohr Hassadim (Light of Mercy) due to the 'Second Restriction' and the Parsa separating GE from AHP; and Gadlut (greatness/adulthood), where Ohr Hochma (Light of Wisdom) can be received. The 'Ascent of the Lower One to the Upper One' describes how a Partzuf (individual soul) can achieve Gadlut by raising MAN and receiving the Upper Light (MAD).

structure_content.chapter_title: Correction in Three Lines & The Hebrew Alphabet
structure_content.summary: Introduces the method of 'Correction in Three Lines' (Right/Hassadim, Left/Hochma, Middle/Zivug) as essential for spiritual balance. The Hebrew alphabet letters are analyzed as symbolic representations of spiritual properties and forces, each 'pleading' for creation based on its unique quality. The Creator's responses to these letters reveal the specific requirements for correcting man's egoism and preparing the world for complete unification. Key letters like Bet (mercy), Tav (truth/judgment), Shin (Shadday/falsehood), Tzadik (righteousness), Peh (liberation/transgression), Ayin (humility/sin), Samech (support), Nun (fall/praises), Mem (King), Lamed (Bina), Chaf (Malchut/throne), and Yod (Hochma) are discussed in detail regarding their spiritual attributes and roles in creation and correction.

Explores pivotal narratives and their Kabbalistic interpretations: 'The Rose' as the Assembly of Israel (Malchut) and its dual nature; 'Supernal Wisdom' and BERESHEET as the six created properties; 'The Lock and the Key' symbolizing concealed wisdom unlocked by Ateret Yesod; 'Avraham' as the property of Hesed and the unlocking of BARAH; 'The Vision of Rabbi Chiya' on collective correction and the Mashiach; 'Who Is Your Partner?' discussing man as the Creator's partner; 'The Donkey Driver' as an auxiliary force for spiritual ascent; 'The Two Points' on fear of the Creator as the beginning of wisdom; 'The Night of the Bride' symbolizing the end of correction; 'Heaven and Earth' detailing Malchut's union with Bina and the role of impure forces; 'Among All the Sages of the Nations of the World' emphasizing faith above reason; and 'He Who Rejoices on Holidays' on altruistic intention. Each narrative is an allegory for internal spiritual processes.

Analyzes the Mitzvot (commandments) not as physical rituals but as spiritual actions for self-correction. The 'First Commandment' (Fear of the Creator) is the foundation. The 'Second Commandment' (Love of the Creator) integrates fear and love. The 'Third Commandment' (Unity) emphasizes merging with the Creator. The 'Fourth Commandment' (Knowledge) focuses on unifying HaVaYaH and Elokim. The 'Fifth Commandment' (Procreation) is about bringing forth holy souls. The 'Sixth Commandment' (Avoiding Corpse) refers to sustaining pure forms. The 'Seventh Commandment' (Circumcision) is the removal of egoistic impurity. The 'Eighth Commandment' (Love an Outsider) means correcting one's own egoistic desires. The 'Ninth Commandment' (Mercy to Needy) is about sharing Light with deprived Malchut. The 'Tenth Commandment' (Tefillin) represents attaining Supernal properties. The 'Eleventh Commandment' (Tithe) is separating holy sparks. The 'Twelfth Commandment' (First Fruits) signifies refraining from premature reception of Light. The 'Thirteenth Commandment' (Redemption of First-born) is weakening the angel of death. The 'Fourteenth Commandment' (Shabbat) is observing rest and receiving Ohr Hochma. All Mitzvot represent internal processes of transforming desires. 'The Intention in the Prayer' and 'Raising a Prayer' emphasize prayer as the central internal work to transform egoism to altruism, leading to the sensation of the Creator.

key_concepts.definition: The ten emanations or attributes of the Creator through which the spiritual worlds are structured and Light is transmitted. The text often reduces them to five: Keter, Hochma, Bina, ZA (Zeir Anpin, combining Hesed, Gevura, Tifferet, Netzah, Hod, Yesod), and Malchut.
A spiritual body or 'face' consisting of a complete set of ten Sefirot, operating with a specific intention. Each Partzuf has a Rosh (head), Toch (interior), and Sof (end). Plural: Partzufim.

A desire or creature. In its corrected state, it is an altruistic desire capable of receiving Light. The human 'heart' refers to the sum of egoistic desires, with a 'small point' being the embryo of a spiritual desire.

Pleasure, the sensation of the Creator. Various types of Light exist: Ohr Hochma (Light of Wisdom/pleasure), Ohr Hassadim (Light of Mercy/bestowal), Ohr Hozer (Returning Light/repelled pleasure), and Ohr Yashar (Direct Light/incoming pleasure). Lights are also categorized by intensity, e.g., NRNHY (Nefesh, Ruach, Neshama, Haya, Yechida).

An anti-egoistic force or strength to resist receiving pleasure for oneself, enabling reception for the Creator's sake (altruistic reception). It determines the quantity of Light a Partzuf can receive.
Man's request, prayer, or aspiration for spiritual ascent and correction, raised from below to the Upper One. It is the sincere desire to receive strength for self-correction.
The Upper Light, strength, or abundance that descends from Above in response to MAN, enabling correction and spiritual elevation.

A ban on the reception of Light for oneself. Tzimtzum Aleph (First Restriction) is the initial ban on Malchut from receiving Light into her truly egoistic desires. Tzimtzum Bet (Second Restriction) is a subsequent restriction where Malchut ascends to Bina, limiting Light reception to GE (Keter, Hochma, GAR of Bina).

A spiritual state where a Partzuf has strength only to bestow (Ohr Hassadim) but cannot receive Ohr Hochma for the Creator's sake. It implies incompleteness, with AHP (will to receive) being concealed or falling below the Parsa.

A spiritual state where a Partzuf, having a sufficient 'screen,' can receive Ohr Hochma for the Creator's sake, filling all its desires with Lights of Hassadim and Hochma. It is attained through the raising of MAN.

A division between altruistic (GE) and egoistic (AHP) Kelim, located between the world of Atzilut and the worlds BYA, or within each Partzuf. It prevents Light from spreading downwards to uncorrected desires.

The final Sefira and the sole creation, representing the egoistic will to receive pleasure. Its correction is the purpose of all spiritual work. In its corrected state, it is called Shechina (Divinity) or Assembly of Israel.
The Sefira representing the property of 'bestowal' or altruism, also called Ima (Mother). It passes Light to ZA. Malchut's ascent to Bina is crucial for her correction.
The Sefira representing the 'Son,' containing six Sefirot (Hesed to Yesod). It accepts Light from Bina and passes it to Malchut. Also referred to as 'Heaven' or 'the Sun'.

Symbols representing spiritual forces, properties, and degrees. Their shapes, order, and numerical values (Gematria) convey specific Kabbalistic information about creation, correction, and the Creator's names. Each letter can represent a Partzuf or a specific property within a Partzuf.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined in this interpretation of The Zohar is a method of 'spiritual ascent' focused on internal correction (Tikkun) of the soul's egoistic desires (Kelim) into altruistic ones. This transformation is achieved through a conscious process of 'raising MAN' (prayer/request) to evoke 'MAD' (Upper Light/strength) from the Creator. The practitioner engages with the teachings of Kabbalah to discern and purify their inner properties, aligning them with the Creator's attribute of bestowal. This involves understanding spiritual states (Katnut and Gadlut), the structure of the spiritual worlds (Sefirot and Partzufim), and the allegorical meanings of the Torah and Hebrew letters as blueprints for spiritual reality. The goal is to build a 'screen' (Masach) to repel selfish reception and receive Light 'for the Creator's sake,' thereby achieving equivalence of form with the Divine.
tools: The Zohar and Torah: Serve as 'guidebooks' and 'instruction manuals' whose allegorical narratives describe the spiritual worlds and the path of correction. Their study provides the 'Light' and understanding needed for ascent.

Hebrew Alphabet, Nekudot, Taamim, Tagin: These elements are not just linguistic but symbolic representations of spiritual forces, properties, and processes. Their analysis aids in understanding the underlying spiritual architecture.
Screen (Masach): A mental and emotional construct, developed through spiritual effort, that serves as a filter to prevent egoistic reception of Light and allows for altruistic reception.
MAN (Mayin Nukvin): The internal 'request' or 'prayer' itself, which is a spiritual tool to draw 'MAD' from Above.
Kabbalist-Teacher: An essential guide in the direct learning of Kabbalah, helping students to acquire analogous sensations of the spiritual world and correct their inner properties.
Bnei Baruch: An organization dedicated to disseminating authentic Kabbalah, providing study materials and guidance for practitioners.
rituals: Raising MAN (Prayer): An internal, heartfelt request to the Creator for the strength and desire to transform egoistic properties into altruistic ones. This is considered the most crucial spiritual action, not a verbal utterance.

Study of Torah/Kabbalah: Engaged not for intellectual knowledge alone, but with the intention of attracting the 'Surrounding Light' that cultivates a desire for correction and reveals spiritual forces and their actions.
Spiritual Circumcision: An internal act of 'cutting off' or rejecting egoistic desires (Orla) to enable the reception of pure Light (Ohr Haya) and purify the soul.

Washing Hands (Spiritual): A symbolic act of removing residual egoistic desires ('impure spirit') from one's purest spiritual desires ('fingertips') before approaching the Creator or uttering blessings.

Observance of Mitzvot (Commandments): Performing actions with pure, altruistic intentions 'for the Creator's sake,' rather than for personal benefit or out of habit. These actions are internal transformations of desires, not merely external rites.

Unification (Zivug): The intentional merging of one's corrected spiritual properties with higher spiritual degrees, especially the union of Malchut with ZA and Bina, to receive Light and attain greater spiritual states.

relevant_quotes.text: Our generation stands at the very threshold of redemption, if we only know how to spread the wisdom of the hidden in the masses. –Baal HaSulam, 'Messiah’s Horn'

I have named the commentary HaSulam (The Ladder) to indicate that the function of my commentary is as the function of any ladder. If you have an attic filled with abundance, you need only a ladder to climb it, and all the bounty in the world will be in your hands.
The Book of Zohar, like the whole of the Torah, speaks exclusively of man (creation) and his relationship with the Creator.

In order to create man in remoteness to Himself, so that man would realize his insignificance and would come independently to the desire to ascend, the Creator created all creation as degrees descending from Him. The Creator’s Light descended along these degrees, and at the lowest degree, created our world and man in it. Having realized his insignificance and wishing to ascend to the Creator, man (to the extent that he wishes to approach the Creator) ascends along the same degrees by which his initial descent took place.

Only he who can create desires that work according to the principle of the second restriction through his own strength and effort, and puts Malchut after Keter-Hochma (thinks in terms of bestowal), can start perceiving through this corrected spiritual sensory organ. Wherever there is a screen, it constitutes that sensory organ with which one can perceive the Upper Light.

Man’s spiritual ascent can be the consequence of two factors: 1. An awakening of a desire from Above, called “special days”—holidays, new moons, Sabbaths. This kind of an ascent is called “an awakening from Above,” and leads to the general ascent of all the worlds ABYA, and, consequently, of all that inhabits them. 2. Man’s efforts in his studies and inner work, his prayer to merit the Creator personally giving him the strength to ascend to a Higher Degree.

The prayer in our heart is the correction within Malchut (the Shechina, the sensation of the Creator, or the common soul of Israel), and the fulfillment of this common soul with the Upper Light (the sensation of the Creator), in accordance with all of its corrected desires. Hence, all our pleas are expressed in plural form, for we pray not for our own soul, but for the common soul of Israel. Naturally, all that is present in the Shechina is subsequently present in every soul of Israel, and vice versa, all that the common soul of Israel lacks is also absent in each soul.

The body’s actions are completely disregarded in Kabbalah. Instead, man’s desire is taken into account and is regarded as an action. In itself, when stripped off the physical body (in which it presently exists), it constitutes man’s inner spiritual action.

critical_analysis.relevance: Rav Laitman's interpretation of The Zohar is profoundly relevant to contemporary Western Esotericism and occult practice, particularly within Kabbalistic traditions. It provides a highly structured, systematic, and psychological framework for understanding spiritual ascent. By emphasizing internal correction over external ritual, it offers a path for individual transformation that resonates with modern seekers. The technical definitions of Sefirot, Partzufim, Lights, and the Hebrew alphabet as spiritual forces provide a precise language for internal operative work. This approach demystifies Kabbalah from mere folklore, presenting it as a science of the soul, directly applicable to a practitioner's inner experience and development.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience is broad, ranging from 'Beginners' seeking answers to life's fundamental questions and an introduction to Kabbalistic concepts, to 'Intermediate' students exploring structured spiritual development, and 'Advanced' practitioners engaging with the technical intricacies of Baal HaSulam's commentaries. It is also suitable for 'All Around' readers interested in spiritual wisdom and 'Textbook' studies of authentic Kabbalistic sources. Essentially, anyone committed to an inner spiritual path, willing to engage in rigorous self-analysis and study for the purpose of altruistic transformation and connection with the Creator, would find this work valuable.
